title.text: Automatic Construction of Weighted String Similarity Measures

entities.text: Automatic Construction of Weighted String Similarity Measures

abstractContent.text: String similarity metrics are used for several purposes in text-processing.
One task is the extraction of cognates from bilingual text.

entities.text: extraction of cognates from bilingual text

abstractContent.text: In this paper three approaches to the automatic generation of language dependent string matching functions are presented.

entities.text: automatic generation of language dependent string matching

introductionContent.text: String similarity metrics are extensively used in the processing of textual data for several purposes such as the detection and correction of spelling errors, for sentence and word alignments, and the extraction of information from monolingnal as well as multi-lingual text.

entities.text: detection and correction of spelling errors

introductionContent.text: One important task is the identification of so-called cognates, token pairs with a significant similarity between them, in bilingual text.

A commonly used technique for measuring string similarity is to look for the longest common subsequence (LCS) of characters in two strings; the characters in this sequence do not necessarily need to be contiguous in the original strings.
The length of the LCS is usually divided by the length of the longer string of the two original tokens in order to obtain a normalized value.
This score is called the longest common subsequence ratio-LCSR.
However, when it comes to different languages, a simple comparison of characters is usually not satisfactory to indicate the total correspondence between words.
Different languages tend to modify loan words derived from the same origin in different ways.
Swedish and English are an example for two languages with a close etymological relation but a different way of spelling fora large set of cognates.
The spelling usually follows certain language specific rules, e.g. the letter 'c' in English words corresponds to the letter 'k' in Swedish inmost cases of cognates.
Rules like this can be used for the recognition of cognates from specific language pairs.

entities.text: recognition of cognates from specific language pairs

introductionContent.text: In this paper three approaches to the automatic generation of language pair specific string matching functions axe introduced.

entities.text: automatic generation of language pair specific string matching

introductionContent.text: They include comparisons at the level of characters and n-grams with dynamic length.
All the three approaches presume linguistic similarities between two languages.
In this study they were applied to word pairs from a Swedish/English text corpus and experimental results are presented for each of them.
